title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #765: Asymptotic Formula for ex(n; C₄)**

This problem asks for the growth rate of ex(n; C₄), the maximum number of edges in an n-vertex graph with no 4-cycle.

**Answer**: ex(n; C₄) ~ (1/2)n^{3/2}

The problem was solved through contributions from Erdős-Klein (1938), Reiman (1958), Erdős-Rényi-Brown, and Füredi (1983).
mathContext: The extremal function ex(n; H) counts the maximum edges avoiding a subgraph H. For C₄ (the 4-cycle), this connects to projective geometry and Sidon sets.

title: 4-Cycle Definition
content:
**hasFourCycle:**

A 4-cycle (C₄) consists of four distinct vertices v₁, v₂, v₃, v₄ with edges:
- v₁ — v₂ — v₃ — v₄ — v₁

Also called a quadrilateral or square in graph theory.
mathContext: The 4-cycle is the smallest even cycle. Its avoidance gives extremal graphs with n^{3/2} edges, unlike odd cycles where ex(n;C_{2k+1}) = Θ(n²).

title: C₄-Free Graph
content:
**isFourCycleFree:**

A graph is C₄-free if it contains no 4-cycle as a subgraph.

Equivalently: no two vertices have more than one common neighbor.
mathContext: C₄-free graphs form a hereditary graph class closed under taking subgraphs.

title: Extremal Function ex(n; C₄)
content:
**ex_C4(n):**

The maximum number of edges in an n-vertex C₄-free graph.

This is a Turán-type extremal function, the central object of Problem #765.
mathContext: Unlike ex(n; K_r) which grows as Θ(n²), forbidding even cycles gives subquadratic growth. For C₄, we get exactly Θ(n^{3/2}).

title: Existence of Extremal Graphs
content:
**Axiom ex_C4_exists:**

For every n, there exists a C₄-free graph on n vertices achieving the maximum edge count.

This is guaranteed by compactness of the finite graph space.

title: Erdős-Klein Upper Bound (1938)
content:
**Axiom erdos_klein_upper:**

ex(n; C₄) = O(n^{3/2})

This was the first upper bound, establishing the order of magnitude. Erdős discovered this while studying B₂ sequences in 1936.
mathContext: The proof uses a double counting argument: if G has m edges, the number of paths of length 2 is at least m²/n. If G is C₄-free, this is at most n(n-1)/2.

title: Reiman's Bounds (1958)
content:
**Axiom reiman_bounds:**

1/(2√2) ≤ lim ex(n;C₄)/n^{3/2} ≤ 1/2

Reiman refined the constant, showing the limit exists and lies in [0.354, 0.5].
mathContext: Reiman's upper bound uses eigenvalue methods. The limit equals exactly 1/2, achieved by projective plane constructions.

title: Projective Plane Construction
content:
**projectivePlaneVertices(q) = q² + q + 1**

For q a prime power, the projective plane PG(2,q) has:
- q² + q + 1 points
- q² + q + 1 lines
- Each point on q + 1 lines
- Each line through q + 1 points

The incidence graph is bipartite with (q+1)² edges per point-line pair, giving (1/2)q(q+1)² total edges.
mathContext: Projective planes exist exactly when q is a prime power. The incidence graph is C₄-free because any two points determine a unique line.

title: Asymptotic Ratio
content:
**asymptotic_ratio(n) = ex(n;C₄) / n^{3/2}**

The ratio that converges to 1/2 as n → ∞.

title: Main Asymptotic Formula
content:
**Axiom asymptotic_formula:**

lim_{n→∞} ex(n;C₄) / n^{3/2} = 1/2

This is the central result of Problem #765, combining Reiman's upper bound with the Erdős-Rényi-Brown construction.
mathContext: The limit is achieved along the subsequence n = q² + q + 1 for prime powers q, where projective planes provide exact matching bounds.

title: Main Theorem (erdos_765)
content:
**Theorem erdos_765:**

For all ε > 0, there exists N such that for n ≥ N:
|ex(n;C₄)/n^{3/2} - 1/2| < ε

This is the formal statement that ex(n;C₄) ~ (1/2)n^{3/2}.

title: Füredi's Exact Result (1983)
content:
**Axiom furedi_exact:**

For q > 13 a prime power and n = q² + q + 1:
ex(n; C₄) = (1/2)q(q+1)²

This gives exact values for infinitely many n, not just asymptotic bounds.
mathContext: Füredi proved that the projective plane construction is exactly optimal for large q. The gap for q ≤ 13 is due to small cases where better constructions may exist.

title: Erdős's Refined Upper Bound (1975)
content:
**Axiom erdos_refined_upper:**

ex(n; C₄) ≤ (1/2)n^{3/2} + (1/4)n + O(n^{1/2})

This improves the leading constant with explicit lower-order terms.

title: Erdős's Conjecture (Disproved)
content:
**erdos_conjecture:**

Erdős conjectured ex(n;C₄) = (1/2)n^{3/2} + (1/4)n + O(√n).

He admitted having 'limited evidence' and would accept O(n) error.
mathContext: This conjecture about lower-order terms was open for decades. Erdős was cautious, noting the lack of strong evidence.

title: Ma-Yang Disproof (2023)
content:
**Axiom ma_yang_disproof:**

Erdős's conjecture is FALSE. Ma and Yang (2023) proved that for a positive density of n:
ex(n;C₄) ≤ (1/2)n^{3/2} + (1/4 - c)n

The coefficient 1/4 can be improved!
mathContext: This recent result shows the exact coefficient of n in the expansion remains open. The constant c > 0 is explicit in their paper.

title: Historical Connection to B₂ Sequences
content:
**Historical Note:**

Erdős first proved ex(n;C₄) ≪ n^{3/2} in 1936 while studying Problem #425 about B₂ sequences. This predates Turán's work by 5 years!

Erdős wrote: 'Being struck by a curious blindness... I did not extend the problem from C₄ to other graphs and thus missed founding an interesting and fruitful new branch of graph theory.'
mathContext: The connection: a C₄-free bipartite graph corresponds to a B₂ set (Sidon set) where all pairwise sums are distinct.

title: B₂ Sequences (Sidon Sets)
content:
**is_B2_sequence:**

A set A ⊆ ℕ is a B₂ sequence if all pairwise sums a + b (a ≤ b) are distinct.

Equivalently: a + b = c + d implies {a,b} = {c,d}.
mathContext: B₂ sets of size n have elements ≤ n² + o(n²). The C₄-free condition ensures at most one common neighbor, analogous to the B₂ uniqueness condition.

title: Fano Plane Example
content:
**Theorem fano_plane_example:**

projectivePlaneVertices(2) = 7

The Fano plane PG(2,2) has 7 points and 7 lines. Its incidence graph has 7 vertices and achieves ex(7;C₄).
mathContext: The Fano plane is the smallest projective plane, with parameters q = 2. It's the unique (7,3,1)-design.

title: PG(2,3) Example
content:
**Theorem pg23_example:**

projectivePlaneVertices(3) = 13

The projective plane PG(2,3) has 13 points and 13 lines.

title: PG(2,4) Example
content:
**Theorem pg24_example:**

projectivePlaneVertices(4) = 21

Note: 4 = 2² is a prime power but not prime. Projective planes exist for all prime powers.

title: PG(2,5) Example
content:
**Theorem pg25_example:**

projectivePlaneVertices(5) = 31

For q = 5, the projective plane has 31 vertices.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**Theorem erdos_765_summary:**

Combines the main results:
1. ex(n;C₄) ~ (1/2)n^{3/2} (the asymptotic formula)
2. projectivePlaneVertices(2) = 7 (concrete example)

Problem #765 is SOLVED.
